title: What Are the Challenges Ahead for Training the Present and Next-Generation Microscopists in the Life Sciences (a.k.a. Structural Cell Biologists)?
content:
Abstract
Becoming a life scientist microscopist involves earning a bachelor’s degree in biology, biomedicine, or a related education program, specializing in microscopy-related areas. Advanced degrees (B.A. Hons., M.A. Res., or Ph.D.) enhance hands-on proficiencies and lay the foundation to become a microscopist or structural cell biologist. Staying updated on technological advancements, networking, and attending relevant microscopy conferences and workshops are central to the success of becoming an established, competent microscopist. Building an academic career in microscopy includes showcasing skills and proficiency in a research field. This involves teaching, scholarly dissemination, and achieving success in awards and grants, which are crucial for entry-level positions in academia. Continuous professional development in specific microscopy interests through workshops, self-education, online resources, or attaining additional certificates or diplomas is essential for academic career advancement, as the science of microscopy is not characterized by a status quo but is evolving at unprecedented speed. Tailoring education and understanding job requirements for academia, research organizations, or industry are critical decisions to align skills with career goals. In this themed contribution, we highlight key considerations for aspiring or junior microscopists to contemplate when building a successful research career in biological microscopy.
